likely_uncovered_areas_or_ambiguities: Detailed per-platform application behavior (macOS, Windows, iOS, Android, Linux, browser-specific extensions) beyond the high-level getting-started docs.
Full plan and licensing matrix for personal, Families, Business, Enterprise, and Extended Access Management packages, including which features are in which tiers.
Deep crypto implementation details and threat model from the 1Password Security Design White Paper were not exhaustively reviewed; only the high-level security model article was analyzed.
Advanced consumer features such as Travel Mode are only mentioned tangentially; their precise behavior, configuration, and edge cases are not fully documented in the pages reviewed.
Managed Service Provider (MSP) capabilities are referenced only at a category level; detailed behavior for cross-tenant administration was not examined.
Trelica by 1Password is described primarily from a product and high-level feature perspective; connector-specific behaviors, data mappings, and workflow semantics are not fully covered.
Some AI-related capabilities (e.g., Agentic Autofill, MCP Server for Trelica) are referenced but detailed enforcement mechanisms and auditability for AI agent actions are not covered.
assumptions_made: Where marketing and support pages described a capability at a high level (for example, Watchtower or Travel Mode), the analysis assumes that the feature exists and works broadly as described, but avoids speculating on internal implementation details.

Behavior that is consistent across multiple documents (for example, use of Secret Key and account password together for encryption) is treated as generally applicable across plans unless a document explicitly limits it to a specific tier.

Developer features like 1Password CLI, Service Accounts, and Connect Servers are assumed to be available to business/enterprise customers with appropriate licensing, as implied by the docs, but exact licensing constraints are not modeled.

Where support index pages list many sub-guides (for example, SCIM integrations, SSO providers), the analysis generalizes capabilities across providers rather than modeling each IdP or SCIM deployment path separately.
Events Reporting and the Events API are treated as the primary source of audit and activity data for 1Password Business; other logging that may exist at infrastructure level is not modeled.

core_product_capabilities.name: Personal and Families Password Vaults and Autofill
core_product_capabilities.description: Provides individual and family accounts with encrypted vaults for storing passwords and other secrets, with autosave and autofill of credentials, payment details, and addresses across major browsers and apps.

main_interfaces.details: Desktop and mobile 1Password apps for Mac, Windows, Linux, iOS, Android, and Apple Watch used to create, view, and manage items and vaults.
Web vault interface at 1Password.com for viewing and managing vault items in a browser.
Browser extensions for Chrome, Safari, Edge, Firefox and others providing autosave and autofill of login, card, and address data.

key_data_involved: Website and application login usernames and passwords
Passkeys for supported sites and apps
Credit and debit card numbers, verification codes, and expiry dates
Postal addresses and personal identity data (name, email, phone, birthdate)
Secure notes and other free-form sensitive text
security_relevant_traits: All item content is end-to-end encrypted and decrypted only on client devices using the account password and Secret Key.
Autofill is domain-aware and will only fill credentials on the sites where they were originally saved, providing phishing resistance.
Clipboard management and auto-lock features reduce the risk of secrets lingering in system clipboards or unlocked sessions.

core_product_capabilities.name: End-to-End Encryption and Secret Key Model
core_product_capabilities.description: Implements a zero-knowledge, end-to-end encryption model where vault data is encrypted using keys derived from the account password and a 128-bit Secret Key, with SRP-based authentication and PBKDF2 key strengthening.

main_interfaces.details: Cryptographic protocols between clients and the 1Password service, not directly exposed as a UI.

key_data_involved: Account password known only to the user
Secret Key stored locally and on the Emergency Kit
Derived encryption keys and initialization vectors
Encrypted vault content and metadata
security_relevant_traits: AES-GCM-256 is used to encrypt vault data, with keys derived using PBKDF2-HMAC-SHA256 from the account password and Secret Key.
Secure Remote Password (SRP) is used so the account password is never transmitted to servers during authentication.
1Password staff cannot access decrypted data because neither the account password nor Secret Key are stored alongside vault data.

data_flows.name: Client Authentication and Vault Access
data_flows.description: Clients authenticate to the 1Password service using SRP so that the account password is never transmitted; encrypted vault blobs are synced, and decryption occurs locally using keys derived from the account password and Secret Key.

data_flows.name: SCIM Provisioning Flow
data_flows.description: Identity providers push SCIM payloads to the customer-hosted SCIM Bridge, which translates them into user and group changes in the 1Password Business account at regular intervals.

data_flows.name: Device Trust Enforcement Flow
data_flows.description: Device Trust agents send device posture data to the Device Trust service, which evaluates checks and signals IdPs or the browser extension to allow or deny authentication and access to apps based on compliance.

data_flows.name: Events Streaming to SIEM
data_flows.description: Events Reporting collects activity and usage events from 1Password Business, exposes them via the Events API, and connector scripts or integrations forward them into SIEM platforms for further analysis.

data_flows.name: Secrets Access via CLI and Service Accounts
data_flows.description: Automation and developer workflows authenticate to 1Password using service-account tokens or CLI integrations, resolve secret references, and inject resolved secrets into environment variables, config files, or runtime contexts.

data_flows.name: Secrets Access via Connect Servers
data_flows.description: Applications within customer infrastructure call Connect servers over HTTP (using SDKs or custom clients) to retrieve secrets for infrastructure services; Connect in turn periodically syncs and caches encrypted data from the central 1Password service.

data_flows.name: Trelica Discovery and Workflow Execution
data_flows.description: Trelica connects to IdPs, HRIS, finance systems, MDM, and SaaS APIs to pull usage and license data, maintains an inventory of apps and assignments, and triggers policy-driven workflows that provision, adjust, or revoke access.

data_flows.name: AI Integration via MCP Server
data_flows.description: Agentic AI systems connect to the Trelica MCP Server to query read-only SaaS governance data, using credentials derived from Trelica and often managed using 1Password secret-distribution patterns.

privileged_operations: Creating, modifying, or deleting vaults and assigning vault permissions for teams and guests in 1Password Business.
Delegating and performing account recovery for family or team members, including bulk recovery using 1Password CLI.
Configuring and managing SCIM Bridge, including mapping IdP groups to 1Password groups and updating allowed domains.
Enabling and configuring Unlock with SSO and associating identity providers with business accounts.
Defining organization-wide security policies such as password requirements, unlock policies, firewall rules, item-sharing rules, and modern-app requirements.
Configuring Device Trust checks, tags, remediation strategies, and enforcement for SSO and non-SSO applications.
Administering Trelica workflows, including automated provisioning, deprovisioning, and license optimization actions across SaaS apps.
Provisioning and managing service accounts and Connect servers, including scope of accessible vaults and secrets.
Issuing and managing Events API tokens and configuring Events Reporting integrations to external SIEM systems.
user_configurable_logic: Customizing item structures with custom fields and security-question answers, including expiry alerts on date fields.
Defining Device Trust compliance checks, weighting, tags, and remediation flows that govern device access.
Writing Trelica policy-based workflows for onboarding, offboarding, and license right-sizing across SaaS applications.
Configuring SCIM sync intervals and confirmation behavior for automated provisioning.
Defining business policies around password strength, two-factor requirements, item sharing, account creation, and unlock behavior.
Defining notification thresholds and Insights alerts for security issues like breached passwords or suspicious sign-in activity.
auth_and_identity_behaviours: User authentication is based on a combination of an account password and Secret Key, with SRP ensuring the password is never transmitted to servers.
End-to-end encryption using AES-GCM-256 ensures that vault data can only be decrypted on client devices that possess the correct keys.
Users can enable two-factor authentication on their 1Password accounts, adding an extra TOTP factor on top of the account password and Secret Key.
Business accounts can integrate with identity providers for SSO login and Unlock with SSO, shifting primary identity management to external IdPs.
Service accounts provide non-human authentication mechanisms with scoped permissions for automation scenarios.
Device Trust augments identity-based authentication by asserting device identity and health before authorizing access to SSO and non-SSO protected applications.
Trelica and Extended Access Management introduce representations of machine and AI identities, which are authenticated and governed similarly to human users for access control.
logging_and_audit_behaviours: The Events API exposes detailed audit logs of administrative changes, vault and item usage, and sign-in attempts for 1Password Business accounts.
Business Insights and reports provide higher-level summaries of password health, breach exposure, and usage statistics for audit and compliance.
Domain breach reports compile known breaches associated with company-owned domains for targeted remediation.
An Activity Log records actions in the business account, which can be filtered and exported for investigations.
Optional telemetry collects usage analytics in a privacy-preserving fashion when users or organizations opt in, but is not required for security or core functionality.
failure_modes: If a user loses both their account password and Secret Key and has no Emergency Kit or recovery path, personal data may be unrecoverable due to strong encryption and zero-knowledge design.

If an organization has insufficient recovery roles (for example, only one family organizer or admin with recovery permissions), loss of that role’s access can render other accounts unrecoverable until support processes or business continuity plans are engaged.
Incorrect time configuration on devices can cause TOTP-based two-factor authentication codes stored in 1Password to fail, blocking sign-ins until clocks are corrected.
Misconfigured Device Trust checks or integrations can block access to critical applications for many users until policies are adjusted or devices are remediated.
SCIM or SSO misconfigurations can lead to unintended user deprovisioning or inability to unlock 1Password with SSO, requiring emergency recovery or reconfiguration.
Improper use of service accounts or Connect (for example, overly broad scopes, long-lived tokens) can exacerbate the impact of credential compromise in automation environments.
If Events Reporting or SIEM integrations fail or become backlogged, security teams may temporarily lose visibility into activity, affecting monitoring and incident response.
